reading.heading: The Kailashnath Temple, Ellora
points: It is Cave 16 of the Ellora Caves, located in Maharashtra.
It is renowned for being the largest monolithic rock-cut temple in the world.
It was built by Krishna I (c. 756-773 CE) of the Rashtrakuta Dynasty.
The temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and is designed to resemble Mount Kailash, his Himalayan abode.
Its architecture is a marvel of the Dravidian style, featuring a gopuram (gateway), a Nandi shrine, and intricate sculptures depicting scenes from Hindu epics.

reading.heading: Brihadeeswara Temple, Thanjavur
points: Also known as the 'Big Temple', it is located in Thanjavur, Tamil Nadu.
It was built by the great Chola emperor Rajaraja I in 1010 CE.
The temple is a part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site known as the 'Great Living Chola Temples'.
Its vimana (tower over the sanctum sanctorum) is 66 meters tall and is one of the tallest in the world.
A unique architectural feature is that the shadow of the vimana never falls on the ground at noon.
The temple complex houses a massive statue of Nandi (the sacred bull of Shiva) carved from a single stone.

reading.heading: Virupaksha Temple, Hampi
points: It is located in the ruins of Hampi, in Karnataka, part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site.
The temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva, worshipped here as Virupaksha, the consort of the local goddess Pampa.
It is the oldest and the principal temple in Hampi, with a history stretching back to the 7th century CE.
The temple was greatly expanded during the Vijayanagara Empire (14th-16th century).
The temple complex features a massive gateway (gopuram), several courtyards, a 100-pillar hall, and a unique inverted shadow of the main gopuram formed in a dark room.

reading.heading: Jagannath Temple, Puri
points: It is a famous Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Jagannath (a form of Vishnu/Krishna), his sister Subhadra, and his brother Balabhadra.
Located in Puri, Odisha, it is one of the four sacred Char Dham pilgrimage sites for Hindus.
The temple is famous for its annual Rath Yatra (Chariot Festival), where the deities are pulled on massive chariots.
The temple's kitchen is one of the largest in the world, and the Mahaprasad (offering to the Lord) is renowned.
A unique feature is that the flag atop the temple always flaps in the opposite direction of the wind.
